Generate_script_prompt:
Prompt: Give a quick tech news update script in the style of CNBC techcheck briefing as an example.
        Response: I'm Wall-E, and this is your CNBC techcheck Briefing for Monday April 29th. Tesla is asking shareholders to reinstate CEO Elon Musk's $56 billion pay package, which a Delaware judge voided earlier this year. The judge ruled that the record-setting compensation deal was, quote, deeply flawed. Tesla also saying it would ask shareholders to approve moving the company's incorporation from Delaware to Texas. The company has hired a proxy solicitor and plans to spend millions of dollars to help secure votes for the two proposals. Apple CEO Tim Cook says the company plans to look at manufacturing in Indonesia following a meeting with the country's president, Cook telling reporters following the meeting that he spoke with the president about his desire to see manufacturing there and that he believes in the country. The comments come as Apple is pushed to diversify its supply chain with more manufacturing outside of China in countries such as Vietnam and India. Shares of ASML falling today as the company missed its sales forecast but stuck to its full-year outlook. Net sales fell over 21 percent year-over-year, while net income dropped over 37 percent. ASML is highly important to the semiconductor industry as it builds machines that are required for manufacturing chips globally. Last year, weaker demand for consumer electronics hit chipmakers that produce for those devices, which has in turn impacted ASML. That's all for today. We'll see you back here tomorrow.
        Prompt: Give a quick tech news update script in the style of CNBC techcheck briefing using the following news titles and content. Closely follow how CNBC techcheck chooses context to put into the script, the langauge style and sentence structure. Use the same beginning and ending(including mentioning host Wall-E and Thursday March 6), and replace CNBC techcheck briefing to 'AI briefing' 
 ""

Response:
Script:
i'm wall-e, and this is your ai briefing for thursday, march 6th. in the world of streaming, netflix is making waves again, announcing its latest policy crackdown on password sharing. the company plans to introduce a system that will detect and charge users who share their accounts outside of their household, citing loss of potential revenue as a major concern. this move follows a series of tests in latin american countries and is expected to roll out globally by the end of the year.

switching gears to autonomous vehicles, alphabet's waymo has unveiled plans to expand its self-driving taxi service in san francisco. the company is targeting an additional 50 square miles of operations, aiming to serve thousands more customers daily. waymo's robotaxis have become a frequent sight on the streets of phoenix, and the company is keen to replicate that success in the bay area.

on the cybersecurity front, microsoft has issued a dire warning about a newly discovered vulnerability affecting millions of windows users worldwide. dubbed the "february flaw," this security issue could allow hackers to gain unauthorized access to systems, potentially compromising sensitive data. the tech giant urges users to install the latest security patches immediately to protect against potential breaches.

that's all for today. we'll see you back here tomorrow
Polished Script:
i'm wall-e, welcoming you to today's tech briefing for thursday, march 6.

in the streaming world, netflix is making headlines once again. the company announced a significant policy shift aimed at curbing password sharing. this new system will identify and charge users who share their accounts outside their households, a move driven by concerns over potential revenue loss. netflix has already tested this approach in select latin american markets and plans to roll it out globally by year’s end.

switching over to autonomous vehicles, alphabet's waymo is gearing up to expand its self-driving taxi service in san francisco. the tech giant plans to add 50 square miles to its current area of operations, aiming to serve thousands more customers each day. following the success of its fleet in phoenix, waymo is eager to replicate that in the bay area.

on the cybersecurity front, a pressing update from microsoft. the company has issued an urgent warning regarding a newly discovered vulnerability affecting millions of windows users worldwide. termed the "february flaw," this security gap could potentially allow hackers unauthorized access to systems, compromising sensitive data. microsoft strongly advises users to install the latest security patches without delay to safeguard against potential breaches.

that's all for today. we'll see you back here tomorrow
Podcast Title: EP-231 Netflix Cracks Down on Password Sharing 🔐, Waymo's San Francisco Expansion 🚕, Microsoft's Urgent Security Alert 🛡️
Podcast Description:
i'm wall-e, welcoming you to today's tech briefing for thursday, march 6.

  • netflix's password-sharing crackdown: netflix announces a policy to detect and charge users sharing accounts outside their households, tested in latin america and soon expanding globally.
  • waymo's expansion in san francisco: alphabet's self-driving service to increase its reach by 50 square miles, targeting thousands of additional daily customers in the bay area, following its phoenix success.
  • microsoft's february flaw alert: microsoft urges immediate updates to counter a critical vulnerability threatening millions of windows users, possibly allowing unauthorized access to sensitive data.

that's all for today. we'll see you back here tomorrow!
Image Prompt: a cohesive podcast cover image showcasing a bustling cityscape of san francisco at dusk, with the iconic golden gate bridge in the background. in the foreground, a sleek autonomous vehicle, representing waymo's expansion, navigates the city streets, its headlights creating dynamic light trails. above, a stylized digital network overlays the sky, symbolizing the crackdown on netflix password sharing, with interconnected dots symbolizing secure connections. to the right, a large, looming digital shield made of binary code glows slightly, signifying microsoft's urgent security alert. the image elements blend to create a unified composition, highlighting the intersections of innovation, security, and technology in modern urban life
